revised_title: The Perpendicular Ascent of Eels: Observations by William Arderon
tldr: William Arderon observed eels ascending perpendicular surfaces, such as flood gates, at a waterworks in Norwich. He noticed that eels would first extend their heads and part of their bodies out of the water, possibly to thicken a slimy substance on their bodies, before sliding up the surfaces with ease. This behavior supports earlier accounts of eels moving across meadows at night.
